name: Louis Pasteur
description: Louis Pasteur was born in 1822 in Dole, France. He earned his undergraduate degree in Bachelors of Letters .Sir Pasteur is one of the most significant contributors to the field of microbiology. He has done extensive research in public health and microbiology. He is considered as one of the founders of modern bacteriology and has been honored as “Father of Bacteriology” and “Father of Microbiology”. He developed the “The Modern Germ Theory of Disease”. He has also contributed in the fields of Pasteurization, Vaccination, Sterilization, Silk Industry and Isomerism. Sir Pasteur won several award during his lifetime and this space wont be sufficient enough to list all of them. Yet, one of the significant awards of his life was being the fellowship of the Royal society of London.

name: Alexander Fleming
description: Alexander felming.

name: Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek
description: Antonie Van Leeuwenhoek was born in 1632 in Delft, Dutch Republic. Talking about his education, Leeuwenhoek never attended any university. He was unaware of other scientific research and rather re-investigated already existing phenomena. He has contributed extensively in the field of microscopy. He designed hand-made microscopes that he used to observe samples like dental plaques and water. Additionally, he was the first to give microscopic observations of organisms and/or cells like bacteria, RBCs, spermatozoa etc. He was also among the first to witness blood flow among capillaries.  He is also credited as being the first person to observe and document the existence of microorganisms. Leeuwenhoek had techniques for lens grinding and microscope construction that were significantly essential for advancing microscopy.Alongside this, his groundbreaking discoveries about the microscope expanded our understanding about microscopes and led to working for better designs.

name: Edward Jenner
description: Edward Jenner-Born on 17th May,1749, Jenner became an orphan at the age of 5 . During his school years, Jenner developed a strong interest in science and nature, which later helped him pioneer the concept of vaccines and later the small pox vaccine, the world's first vaccine.Jenner is known as father of immunology due to his efforts of saving millions of people from the threatening disease of small pox.

name: Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis
description: Ignaz Philipp Semmelweis was born on July 1 at  Tabán, Budapest, Hungary, 1818. He was a scientist of Hungarian and German descent, an early pioneer of sterilization, and was called the 'Savior of the Mother'. Postpartum disease, also known as puerperal fever or puerperal fever and caused by bacteria present in the body after birth, emerged in the 19th century and often causes death. Semmelweis found that infection could be reduced by health care workers washing their hands during maternity meetings. In 1847, he recommended washing hands with chlorinated lime, which caused the death of the hospital quack at the First Obstetrics Clinic of the Vienna General Hospital at the midwife hospital. On 1 July 1846, Semmelweis was appointed assistant to Johann Klein at the First Obstetrics Clinic of the Vienna General Hospital. A similar position in U.S. nursing homes would be “primary residents.” His job is to check the patient's medication status every morning. Tour the church, monitor the quality of birth, educate doctors, and act as the 'author' of documents. Semmelweis was concerned that the death rate from puerperal fever was higher in his first hospital than in his second hospital. This makes me sad and life is empty. The two meetings were used in almost the same way, and Semmelweis set out to judge all the differences. 'Overcrowding' is prohibited because deaths are fewer, although other hospitals are always overcrowded. Since both meetings were close to the region, the decision was made based on the weather. She also changed her main job to giving birth and asked an employee to perform the hospital's final rite, which would scare women and cause them to become feverish after giving birth. Semmelweis's idea was confirmed in 1847 when his close friend Jakob Kolletschka died in an accident. Use a student scalpel during autopsy to perform an autopsy. Kolecka's autopsy revealed lesions similar to those seen in women who died of puerperal fever. Semmelweis could not help suggesting a connection between poor hygiene and puerperal fever. He pointed out that from the hospital room to the first obstetrics hospital, he and the medical researchers carried 'cadaver patches' in their hands during the examination. This explains why the student midwife at the reserve hospital was not working. Mortality was lower in postmortem and unexposed subjects. The alleged origin of the complaint has not been verified in Vienna. Therefore, Semmelweis concluded that some unknown 'physical substance' caused postpartum diarrhea. He introduced the rule of using chlorinated lime (calcium hypochlorite) for hand washing during physical and medical examinations. He did this because he found that these chlorination products were effective in removing foul odors from infected tissue, thereby reducing the potential for disease-causing bacteria to 'poison' or 'cadaver' workers suspected of being infected with this equipment. The result was a reduction of 90 deaths at the primary hospital and a similar death rate at the backup hospital. The death rate in April 1847 was 18.3. After hand washing was introduced in mid-May, the death rate was 2.2 in June, 1.2 in July and 1.9 in August, while the number of deaths was zero in the next two periods for the first time since the disease first appeared in the body. . months. Semmelweis is now known as the colonizer of the antimicrobial law. In 2008, Semmelweis was awarded the Austrian coin 'Ignak Semmelweis Prize', Hungary's most prestigious medical award. Semmelweis thought there was a connection between the dead. It has been speculated that some of the 'death stains' on the tissues of the corpse were left at the hands of yellow charlatans and medical scientists during pregnancy; diseases are carried and patches are changed for women in need. He is also known as the 'Father of Disease Prevention' and the 'Savior of Mankind'. He was the first in medical history to demonstrate to doctors that puerperal fever (also known as 'puerperal fever') was contagious and that its spread could be greatly reduced by proper hand washing. He died on August 13, 1865 at Oberdöbling, Vienna, Austria

name: Hans Christian Joachim Gram
description: Hans Christian Joachim Gram was born in 1853, in Copenhagen, Denmark . He did his studies at the University of Copenhagen. He gained knowledge about pharmacology and microscopy. He worked as a botany assistant. His main field of career was bacteriology. In Berlin, Gram developed the now-known technique of Gram Staining, a method for distinguishing between two major bacterial classes in 1884. His initial works include studying human red blood cells. He was also one of the first who recognised that macrocytes were characteristic of pernicious anemia.Gram’s work over gram staining earned him international reputation.

name: Charles Louis Alphonse Laveran
description: Charles Louis Alphonse Laveran was born in1845 in Paris, France. He partook medical studies from University of Strasbourg. In the Franco-German War, he served as an army surgeon. He later joined the Pasteur institute, Paris, where he practiced and taught about military medicine. During his service as a military surgeon in Algeria, he discovered the causative agents of infectious disease such as malaria and trypanosomiasis which are parasitic protozoans. He became chief of honorary service at Pasteur institute, where he won the Nobel prize. He established the laboratory of tropical medicine at Pasteur institute with half of his Nobel prize money. He was selected as a member of the French Academy of Sciences in 1893, and later, also became Commander of the National Order of the Legion of Honour in 1912.

name: Joseph Lister
description: Joseph Lister was born in 1827, in England. Joseph Lister was unable to attend universities post his schooling due to religious tests that barred him. Owing to this, he attended University College London Medical School and completed a course in botany. Some of Sir Lister’s works include the mechanism of coagulation of blood and role of blood vessels in first stage of inflammation. He later worked with antisepsis wherein he tried to an antiseptic barrier between the wounds and air. His antisepsis work was used on a large scale during the Franco-German war. He was the first to apply the science of germ theory to surgery. His principles made surgery safe and continue to save countless lives. Joseph Lister was awarded several honors for his contributions to science and non-science fields.

name: Fanny Hesse
description: Fanny was a microbiologist who was born on 22nd june, 1850, new york as ‘Angelina Fanny Eilshemius’ and died on 1st december, 1934. She studied French and home economics at finishing school in switzerland.In 1872, while traveling in Germany with Eugenie, she met Eugenie's brother, her future husband and research partner, Walther Hess. The couple became engaged in 1873, and they married in 1874 with a wedding held in Geneva finally becoming fanny hess. In addition to her housekeeping duties, Hesse gives her best to assist her husband through preparing bacterial growth media, cleaning equipment, and producing illustrations for scientific publications. After  becoming familiar with her husband's work she performed a role similar to a modern-day medical technologist, She also performed a role as a scientific illustrator, drawing highly accurate watercolor images showing each growth phase of intestinal bacterial culture when viewed under magnification, and her illustrations were included in her husband's work that was published in 1908 as part of her work in the development of medical illustration. Hess helped to coat test tubes with gelatin for her husband to use in growing microorganisms but they discovered that gelatin easily melted on warm days, destroying some of the bacteria. With her technical duties, she also helped through her artistic abilities to draw the same pictures of bacterial colonies as viewed under a microscope in the different phases of bacteria growth to use in her husband's journal publications. She recommended agar as a plating medium and she was also helping her husband to culture air-borne bacteria. In 1881, while her husband was working in the laboratory of  Robert Koch who was a German physician and microbiologist, they  had tried to use potato slices as a medium to culture pure colonies but it was unsubstantial, they tried  to use a nutrient-rich gelatin media, which still did not provide adequate stability for producing cultures for examination. After so many unsuccessful attempts of culturing microorganisms on gelatin mediums, Hesse suggested that agar was preferable to gelatin for cultivating bacteria and other microorganisms. She was knowing about the properties of agar as a gelling agent, able to maintain its physical properties at warm temperatures, through her usage of it at home. She had learned about agar from her mother’s friend. She was first to suggest using agar as an alternative to gelatin; they were first to use agar as a common gelling agent for producing media capable of culturing microorganisms at high temperatures. The main difference between agar and gelatin was agar could remain solid at temperatures up to 90°C while settling at temperatures below 45°C, gelatin liquified at 37°C, which made it an unsuitable medium to plate many types of bacteria in laboratory conditions. The agar 'dessert medium' invented by Hesse.

name: Martinus Willem Beijerinck
description: Martinus Willem Beijerinck was born in 1851 in Holland, Amsterdam.  He completed his graduation from Delft and obtained doctorate from the University of Leiden in 1877.He was also one of the founders of virology and environmental microbiology. He founded the discipline of virology with his discovery of viruses (TMV). he called that virus “contagium vivum fluidum”. Beijerinckia (a genus of bacteria), beijerinckiaceae (a family of hyphomicrobiaceae) and Beijerinck crater are named after him. The M.W.Beijerinck virology prize is also awarded in his honor. Earlier he studied plant galls, swellings of plant tissue now known to be caused by the invasion of various infectious agents. He isolated bacillus radicicola, the nodule organism of leguminous plants in 1888. His studies are essential for soil science, azotobacter, sulfur bacteria and on denitrification (which convert soil nitrates to free atmospheric nitrogen). He was the first who said that viruses are reproducing entities, but it is different from other living organisms. He also visited the laboratory of German bacteriologist Robert Koch to learn. His works and scientific reputation were expanding and  in 1895 the Dutch government created a special position for him at the delft polytechnical school. He remained there till his retirement in 1921.

name: Marjory Stephenson
description: MS

name: Emil von Behring
description: Emil von Behring was born in Hansdorf in 1854. Behring received his medical degree in 1878 from the Friedrich-Wilhelms-Institute, and became an assistant to Robert Koch in 1889.  Behring, became an assistant at the Institute for Infectious Diseases. He started his studies with development of a therapeutically active first of a kind serum against diphtheria.  He received many awards, few significant being the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for his work on serum therapy-first of the Nobel Prizes given in the field of immunology.

name: Heinrich Hermann Robert Koch
description: Robert Koch was born in 1843, in Clausthal, Northwest Germany. He had a natural interest in natural science and entered the University of Göttingen to study the same. But later on he changed his area of study to medicine. Sir Koch performed elaborate inoculation studies using several animal species and discovered rod shaped bacterium in the blood of affected animals. Alongside this, he also discovered the route of their transmission. He studied illness caused by microorganisms, discovered and described   TB bacterium in 1882. In 1883 he discovered an organism which causes cholera and worked on how it is transmitted and also developed a vaccination for rinderpest. His main works Known are Koch's postulates, Koch–Pasteur rivalry ,Bacterial culture method, Germ theory of disease, Medical microbiology ,Discovery of anthrax bacillus ,Discovery of tuberculosis bacillus and tuberculin for which he won nobel prize. Koch was made a Knight Grand Cross in the Prussian Order of the Red Eagle,  on 19 November 1890, It was awarded to both military personnel and civilians, to recognize valor in combat, excellence in military leadership, long and faithful service to the kingdom and elected a Foreign Member of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in 1897.  He won The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1905 for his investigations and discoveries in relation to tuberculosis (TB). In order to honor Robot Koch, In 1906, because of his research on tuberculosis and tropical diseases, he was honored by the Order Pour le Merite. The Robert Koch Foundation, founded in 1907, is a not for profit foundation for the promotion of medical progress in Berlin. The Foundation has the goal of supporting the fight against infectious diseases and other epidemics This Foundation awards each year a number of prestigious scientific awards: the Robert Koch Award, one of the highest-ranking scientific awards in Germany, the Robert Koch Gold Medal in 1980. The Robert Koch Award is one of the most esteemed scientific awards in the Federal Republic of Germany. The prize is awarded annually to researchers for outstanding and internationally recognized scientific achievements. Emperor Wilhelm I also awarded him the Order of the Crown, 100,000 marks and appointment as Privy Imperial Councillor, Surgeon-General of Health Service, and Fellow of the Science Senate of Kaiser Wilhelm Society.

name: Charles Jules Henri Nicolle
description: CHARLES JULES HENRI NICOLLE was born in 1866 in Rouen, France. His works include many significant scientific contributions like discovery of the mode of  transmission of typhus fever and tick fever. He even introduced vaccination for Malta fever.Alongside these, Sir Charles has also studied cancer, scarlet fever, rinderpest, measles, influenza, tuberculosis and trachoma and identified the parasitic organism Toxoplasma gondii within the tissues of the gundi (Ctenodactylus gundi) one commonly found in AIDS patients.He was awarded with several awards, one of the prestigious being the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine.

name: Sir Ernst Boris Chain
description: Sir Ernst Boris chain was a British biochemist who was born on 19th june, 1906, in berline and died at the age of 73 on 12th august, 1979, casterbar, ireland. He studied chemistry at Friedrich Wilhelm university. When nazis came in power, Chain knew that he was not safe in Germany and went to England on 2nd april, 1933. With the help of J.B.S. haldane, he obtained a position at university college hospital, landon. After that, he studied at fitzwilliam college, cambridge as PhD student and there he started working on phospholipids under the guidance of sir frederick gowland hopkins. In 1935, he became lecturer of pathology at oxford university. During this period he worked on many topics including tumor metabolism, lysozymes, snake venoms and biochemistry techniques. In 1939, he investigated natural antibacterial agents which was synthesized by microorganisms with Howard florey. Chain and florey together worked on therapeutic action and its chemical composition. They discovered techniques to isolate and concentrate the germ killing agents in penicillin. For this work, both chain and florey won the nobel prize in physiology or medicine. Chain was also working on theorizing the beta-lactam structure of penicillin in 1942, which was later confirmed by Dorothy hodgkin through x- ray crystallography. Towards the end of world war II, he got to know that his mother and sister had been killed by nazis. He returned to Britain in 1964 and became founder and head of the biochemistry department at Imperial college, london. He stayed there till his retirement and also did specialization in fermentation technologies.

name: Max Theiler
description: Max Theiler was born in 1899, in South Africa.He received his MD degree in 1922 and later in 1922 joined the department of tropical medicine at Harvard Medical School, Boston.Max Theiler’s early works include amoebic dysentery and rat bite fever. He significantly worked on yellow fever, discovering its cause and transmission, alongwith his colleagues. Dr. Theiler and his colleagues worked on vaccines. He worked on the causes and immunology of certain disorders like Weil’s disease. He also worked on dengue fever and Japanese encephalitis. One of the significant and intriguing issues was poliomyelitis which was later called Theiler’s disease (encephalomyelitis).Dr. Theiler has been a contributor to two books, Viral and Rickettsial Infections of Man (1948) and Yellow Fever (1951). He had  also wrote numerous papers in The American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Annals of Tropical Medicine and Parasitology.Honors awarded to him include the Chalmer’s Medal of the Royal Society of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene (London, 1939), the Flattery Medal (Harvard, 1945), and the Lasker Award of the Lasker Foundation (1949).He was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 1951 for developing a vaccine against yellow fever.⁸Max Theiler died on August 11, 1972, at the age of 73.

name: Selman Abraham Waksman
description: SELMAN ABRAHAM WAKSMAN was born in 1888 in Nova Pryluka, Ukraine. He graduated with a science in agriculture degree from Rutgers University, followed by a master's degree from the same university. He later was awarded a doctor of philosophy in biochemistry.Selman has spent his time researching about various aspects of decomposition of soil living organisms. This research led to the discovery of streptomycin and several other antibiotics. He even introduced procedures that have led to the development of many others antibiotics. He also spent his time studying soil fungi.Selman received awards like the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, Leeuwenhoek Medal and Albert Lasker Award for Basic Medical Research. He was also known as an inventor, biochemist and microbiologist.

name: Stanley Norman Cohen
description: STANLEY NORMAN COHEN was born in 1935 in New Jersey, United States. He graduated with a BS degree and later moved to complete an MD from University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine. He worked with nerve growth factor and epidermal growth factor. He is an American biochemist who, along with Rita Levi-Montalcini, was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine for the isolation of nerve growth factor and the discovery of epidermal growth factor. In 1979 elected to the National Academy of Sciences. Alongside these, Stanley Norman Cohen also received Wolf Prize in Medicine, National Inventors Hall of Fame and many more.

name: Herbert Wayne 'Herb' Boyer
description: Born and raised in western Pennsylvania, Boyer attended St. Vincent’s College in Latrobe, where he enrolled in premedical studies. He was soon captivated by research, however, and chose to major in chemistry and biology. He completed a PhD in biochemistry at the University of Pittsburgh and then went on to a postdoctoral fellowship at Yale University. In 1966 he accepted an appointment at UCSF, which was becoming a center of excellence in the several disciplines that contributed to the emerging field of biotechnology.The first success of the Boyer-Cohen collaboration occurred in spring 1973 and involved one of Cohen’s plasmids, pSC101. Plasmids were already known to transfer drug resistance among bacteria, and this one could make E. coli resistant to the antibiotic tetracycline. The plasmid pSC101 was cleaved by EcoRI at only one site, leaving intact the plasmid’s ability to replicate. When the linearized pSC101 DNA was mixed with other DNA that had been cleaved by the same enzyme, the complementary ends of fragments from both sources of DNA joined together into new loops. Treatment with another enzyme closed the still-visible nicks in the DNA loops, which were then introduced into calcium chloride–treated bacteria. The bacteria were spread on a culture containing tetracycline, and only the bacteria with the rDNA plasmids survived.Boyer and Cohen soon moved on to more complicated cloning experiments. They joined tetracycline-resistant plasmids with kanamycin-resistant plasmids—kanamycin being another antibiotic—and inserted them in E. coli. Next they showed that genetic materials could indeed be transferred between species, thereby disproving a long-held myth. They snipped a piece of Staphylococcus plasmid (Staphylococcus is the bacteria responsible for staph infections), spliced it with one of the many E. coli plasmids, and inserted the whole in E. coli. The DNA from Staphylococcus, a different species of bacteria, was successfully propagated in E. coli. An even greater triumph of interspecies cloning was the insertion into E. coli of genes taken from the South African clawed frog.Boyer received the Biotechnology Heritage Award in 2000 from  the Science History Institute, and the Biotechnology Innovation Organization.Cohen was honored with the 2016 Biotechnology Heritage Award in recognition of his revolutionary work in creating rDNA plasmids, a foundation of all biotechnology .Boyer also received the Society of Chemical Industry’s Perkin Medal in 2007 and the Winthrop-Sears Medal in 2005.

name: Georges Jean Franz Köhler
description: George Jean Franz Kohler was born in 1946 in Munich, Germany. He did his post doctoral research at the laboratory of molecular biology in Cambridge, UK. He developed laboratory tools for investigating the mechanism of diversity of antibodies. He also invented hybridoma techniques for the production of antibodies. He worked on development of transgenic mice as a tool to understand the mechanism of self tolerance. In 1986, Kohler was appointed as director of the Max Planck Institute of Immunobiology. Apart from this, Sir Kohler won several awards.

name: César Milstein
description: CESAR MILSTEIN was born in 1927 in Bahía Blanca, Argentina. He developed a hybridoma technique for the production of monoclonal antibodies and also worked over antibody research.  He won several awards like the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine and earned several fellowships like Fellowship of Royal Society in 1975.

name: Pushpa Mittra Bhargava
description: Pushpa Mittra Bhargava was born in 1928 in Ajmer. He was a postdoctorate in synthetic organic chemistry.  He is the founder of Centre for Cellular and Molecular Biology, a federally funded research institute, in Hyderabad .He was awarded the Padma Bhushan and the Legion of Honour, among the many many laurels and titles .

name: Károly Ereky
description: Karoly Ereky was Hungarian agricultural engineer who was born on 20th October 1878, in Esztergom, Hungary as Károly WittmannIn and in1893 he changed his name to Ereky. On 19th September 1946, Ereky was sent to the prison of Vác for 12 years by the People's Tribunal for his counter-revolutionary role in Hungary. He died in prison on 17 June 1952 at the age of 74. He received a degree in technical engineering at Technical University of Budapest in 1900. until 1905, he worked as a machine designer for several companies in the paper and food industry in Vienna, Austria. After that, he became an assistant professor in József Technical University.In 1919 he became the Hungarian food Minister.  Ereky was also good at speaking both German and English. Hundreds of his written publications were written in Hungarian and published in German. In 1922, he wrote a book on the chlorophyll mechanism and how it can be used for animal feeding. In 1925, he wrote a book on leaf proteins as a possible food source which he also promoted as a commercial product. In 1919, in a book he published in Berlin called Biotechnologie der Fleisch-, Fett- und Milcherzeugung im landwirtschaftlichen Grossbetriebe (Biotechnology of Meat, Fat and Milk Production in an Agricultural Large-Scale Farm), here first he coined the term “biotechnology” where he explained  a technology based on converting raw materials into a more useful product. He built a slaughterhouse for a thousand pigs and also with space for 50,000 pigs, raising over 100,000 pigs a year- a fattening farm. The enterprise was enormous, becoming one of the largest and most profitable meat and fat operations in the world. Later, he developed a theme that would be reiterated through the 20th century: biotechnology could provide solutions to societal crises, such as food and energy shortages. For Ereky, the term 'biotechnology' indicated the process by which raw materials could be biologically upgraded into socially useful products.

name: Rudolf Jaenisch
description: Rudolf Jaenisch was born in 1942 in Poland. He earned a doctorate in medicine from University of Munich. He is currently a professor of biology at MIT. He earlier headed the department of Tumor Virology at the University of Hamburg. Later he became a founding member of Whitehead Institute. His known works make him renowned for epigenetic mechanisms of gene regulation, therapeutic cloning and embryonic stem cell research, giving him the title of “Father of Transgenic Animals”.  He focused on creating genetically modified mice to study cancer epigenetic reprogramming and neurological diseases. He also created the first transgenic model to showcase use of therapeutic cloning to correct genetic defects. He won many awards, few being Gruber Prize in Genetics and Robert Koch prize .

name: Paul Berg
description: Paul Berg was born in 1926 in New York, United States. He earned a bachelors degree in biochemistry and later a doctorate in biochemistry as well. He contributed to the 1980 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, along with Walter Gilbert and Frederic Sanger. He also worked nucleic acids, DNA splicing and nucleic acid base sequences and recombinant DNA technology.In 1966, he became a member of the American Academy of Business and Science and the National Academy of Sciences. He was also admitted as a member of the American Philosophical Association. He won the American Academy of Achievement's Gold Plate award in 1989 and was named a Foreign Fellow of the Royal Society (ForMemRS) in 1992. In 2005, he was awarded the Biotechnology Heritage Award by the Biotechnology Industry Organization (BIO) and the Chemical Heritage Foundation. In 2006, he received Wonderfest's Carl Sagan Award for Scientific Research. He died on February 15, 2023 at  Stanford, California, United States.

name: Vinay K. Nandicoori
description: Vinay Kumar Nandicoori was born in 1969 in India. He did his M.Sc in biotechnology from Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Bombay, India and PhD from the Indian institute of science. After gaining PhD, he worked at the University of Virginia and Texas A&M University. One of his known studies are on the kinase-mediated signaling networks in Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative pathogen of tuberculosis. The Department of Biotechnology of India honored him with the National Bioscience Award, one of the highest Indian science awards for his contribution to biosciences.  National Academy of science, India elected him as a member of the Guha research conference and awarded the NASI-Scopus Young Scientist Award.

name: Sudhanshu Vrati
description: Sudhanshu Vrati was born in 1960 in Uttar Pradesh, India. He completed his M.Sc in microbiology from G.B. Pant university of agriculture and technology, DIIT in biochemistry engineering from Indian institute of technology (IIT), Delhi, India and doctoral studies from the Australian National University. He initially worked at Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization (CSIRO) Center, Sydney. When he returned to India, he joined the National Institute of Immunology as a scientist. While working as senior scientist, he was appointed as the dean at the translational health science and technology institute (THSTI) in 2005. His early research work focused on mechanisms of receptor binding and entry, molecular mechanism of virus replication, assembly, egress as well as the clinical development of an oral rotavirus vaccine. After that he started concentrating on the development of DNA vaccines and his work was published as an article, DNA vaccines: getting closer to becoming a reality in 2013. His studies on rat brain helped to identify Mov34 protein later which was used in the development of vaccines for flaviviral diseases like Japanese encephalitis and Dengue.dHe several awards like VASVIK Industrial Research Award , Professor KP Bhargava Memorial Medal and Alembic Award .India once again honored him with the NASI-Reliance Platinum Jubilee Award in 2006.The Department of Biotechnology gave him the Tata Innovation Fellowship, in 2009 and the High Commission of Australia in India awarded him the Australian Alumni Award in 2010 .

name: Motilal Madan
description: Madan was born in 1939 in Srinagar. He is the recipient of PhD from University of Missouri. Madan served as Project Director of Embryo Transfer Technology at India's premier dairy research institute, the National Dairy Research Institute (NDRI). He led a research team at the institute that conducted the world's first successful in vitro fertilization of a buffalo, resulting in the birth of a calf, named 'Pratham, in November 1990. Sir Madan received several awards during his professional tenure and has even garnered fame through his publications of 432 research articles and policy papers in international and national refereed journals – including 226 original research papers. His pioneering research areas include  reproductive endocrinology, embryo biotechnology, in vitro fertilization and cloning.

name: Keith Henry Stockman Campbel
description: Keith Henry Stockman Campbell was born in 1954 in Birmingham, England. He got educated in embryo growth and cell differentiation. He earned a bachelors in microbiology and an ultimate degree of PhD. He was the first to clone an animal in 1996 a Finnish Dorset sheep named. He was Professor of Animal Development at the University of Nottingham. He produced lambs from embryonic cells that differentiated in culture. He worked with cell cycle of embryonic cells. In 2008, he received the Shaw Prize in Medicine and Life Sciences together with Ian Wilmut and Shinya Yamanaka. In 2015, he was posthumously awarded the Pioneer Award by the International Embryo Transfer Society.

name: Sir Ian Wilmut
description: Ian Wilmut, in full Sir Ian Wilmut, was on  born July 7, 1944 in Hampton Lucy, Warwickshire, England .He graduated from Nottingham in 1967 with a degree in agricultural science, Wilmut entered Darwin College at Cambridge University.Wilmut was awarded his PhD in 1971 for his thesis on deep freeze preservation of boar semen. After receiving his doctorate, he continued his research at the Animal Breeding Research Station (ABRS), located in Roslin, a short distance from Edinburgh, Scotland. (The ABRS would be renamed the Roslin Institute in 1993.) .At the Roslin Institute, Wilmut worked with Keith Campbell. Together, they realized that in order to make an already differentiated cell behave like an embryonic cell, it would be necessary to cause the cell to become quiescent, or, in effect, to hibernate. They induced quiescence in differentiated embryonic cells and implanted them in the wombs of surrogate sheep. The result of this process was manifested in two sheep, Megan and Morag, born in July 1995. The next breakthrough for Wilmut and his team came in July 1996 with the birth of Dolly. Named after country singer Dolly Parton, the cloned Finn Dorset sheep was produced from the combination of an ovum and an adult mammary cell’s quiescent nucleus. The mammary cells, harvested from the udder of an ewe, had been made to hibernate through starvation, which caused near-immobility in the differentiated nucleus. The quiescent nuclei could then be injected into denucleated sheep ova and implanted into a surrogate mother. Here, the nucleus would resume activity and the cell would behave like a regular embryonic cell. Dolly’s birth and, more importantly, the methods by which she was created, drew much attention to Wilmut and his team, both in the scientific community and in popular culture. He has received many honors, including the Order of the British Empire in 1999, induction into the Royal Society in 2002, the Paul Ehrlich Prize in 2005, and the prestigious Shaw Prize in 2008. He was knighted in 2008. Sir Ian Wilmut, the man who led the team that created Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be cloned from an adult cell, has died, aged 79.

name: Piet Bergveld
description: Piet Bergveld was born in 1940 in Oosterwolde, Netherlands. He completed his masters degree in electrical engineering from the University of Eindhoven, Eindhoven and later earned his Ph.D. degree from the University of Twente, Netherlands. In 1970, he developed the ion-sensitive field-effect transistor (ISFET) sensor.Strikingly different, Piet Bergveld was awarded the Jacob Kistemaker [nl] prize and was later elected as a member of the Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences in 1997.

name: Arthur D. Riggs
description: Arthur Dale Riggs was born in 1939 in California.Riggs completed his undergraduate degree in chemistry from University of California, and later his doctoral thesis work at the California Institute of Technology with Herschel K. Mitchell, and  obtained a  Ph.D. in biochemistry in 1966. In 1977, Sir Riggs created the first artificially synthesized gene and human protein which he later used for producing humulin-a first human insulin from bacteria.Sir Riggs later developed recombinant DNA technology that produced human monoclonal antibodies useful for diseases like cancers and HIV. He was recognized for this lifetime of achievements by his election to the National Academy of Sciences in 2006.Alongside this, he was felicitated with Distinguished Alumni Award from University of California, was elected to the National Academy of Sciences.

name: Emmanuelle Marie Charpentier
description: Prof. Dr. Emmanuelle Marie Charpentier was born in 1968 in Juvisy-sur-Orge, France .She completed her undergraduate studies in biochemistry at Pierre and Marie Curie University (later part of Sorbonne University). She then moved to partake doctorate studies. In 2004, Charpentier discovered RNA molecule involved in the regulation of virulence-factor synthesis in Streptococcus pyogenes .In 2012, Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna developed a method for high-precision genome editing. Charpentier has worked  on deciphering the molecular mechanisms of a bacterial immune system, called CRISPR/Cas9, and repurposing it into a tool for genome editing. Earned a Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020 in joint association with Jennifer A. Doudna for the development of a method for genome editing .Charpentier received several other awards like Canada Gairdner International Award (2016) and the Kavli Prize in Nanoscience (2018). She was an elected member of the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences (2015) and the European Academy of Sciences and Arts (2018)

name: Jennifer Anne Doudna
description: Jennifer anne doudna was born in 1964 in Washington, D.C., United States. She earned a PhD from Harvard Medical School.Doudna has done pioneering work in CRISPR gene editing . She has also made many fundamental contributions in biochemistry and genetics. She developed a method for genome editing alongwith a colleague. She has also worked on structure of ribozyme. Doudna was one of the first women to receive a Nobel in sciences. Apart from Nobel laurel, she has also won several other awards like Searle Scholar, Beckman Young Investigators Award etc.

name: Yuan Longping
description: Yuan Longping, internationally known as the ‘father of hybrid rice was a Chinese plant scientist whose breakthroughs in developing high-yield hybrid strains of rice helped to alleviate famine and poverty across much of Asia and Africa. Yuan Longping was born in Beijing in 1930 and received his agronomic degree from Southwest Agricultural College (now Southwest University) in 1953. Subsequently, he began his teaching career at Anjiang Agricultural School in Hunan Province, China.  Mr. Yuan’s work on hybrid rice started in the 1960 with the backdrop of an unprecedented famine. He reported findings on mutated male-sterile rice plants in the Chinese Science Bulletin in 1966. As these experiments did not show significant advantage over common rice, he started cross breeding with a wild rice species, known as ‘wild abortive’.Subsequent experiments, involving a large team of scientists and farmers across the country, proved successful as the new hybrid rice performed better than conventional rice. By 1979, this technique for hybrid rice was being introduced in the United States. Mr. Yuan’s rice accomplishments continued over the years.The late 1990s saw the launch of the Super Hybrid Rice Breeding Research Programme, under Mr. Yuan’s guidance, aiming to carry out national demonstration and promotion of the research results of super rice. In the next decade, China doubled rice production while reducing use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides.Yuan Longping’s hybrid rice varieties eventually became dominant in China’s paddies and in overall rice production. And China has dominated world hybrid rice production since 2004.Mr Yuan Longping was credited with a long list of awards and prizes, including China’s first special invention award in 1981, the UNESCO Prize for Science in 1987, the Nikkei Asia Award in 1996, the State Preeminent Science and Technology Award in 2000, the Wolf Prize in Agriculture and the Word Food Prize in 2004.Mr Yuan Longping passed away on 22 May 2021 at the age of 91, in Changsha, Hunan Province, China.

name: Kary Banks Mullis
description: Kary Banks Mullis, Nobel Prize winning chemist, was born on December 28, 1944, in Lenoir, North Carolina.He received his Bachelor of Science degree from the Georgia Institute of Technology and Ph.D. degree from the University of California, Berkeley, where he later also lectured in biochemistry there until 1973. Dr. Mullis later joined the Cetus Corporation in Emeryville, California, where he worked as a DNA chemist . He contributed his seven years out there conducting research on oligonucleotide synthesis and inventing the polymerase chain reaction.In 1986, he was named director of molecular biology at Xytronyx, Inc. in San Diego, where he worked in DNA technology and Photochemistry. In 1987 began consulting on nucleic acid chemistry for more than a dozen corporations, including Angenics, Cytometrics, Eastman Kodak, Abbott Labs, Milligen/Biosearch, and Specialty Laboratories.Dr. Mullis served on the board of scientific advisors of several companies, provided expert advice in legal matters involving DNA, and was a frequent lecturer at college campuses, corporations and academic meetings around the world.The process, which Dr. Mullis conceptualized in 1983, is hailed as one of the monumental scientific techniques of the twentieth century. A method of amplifying DNA, PCR multiplies a single, microscopic strand of the genetic material billions of times within hours. The process has multiple applications in medicine, genetics, biotechnology, and forensics. PCR, because of its ability to extract DNA from fossils, is in reality the basis of a new scientific discipline, paleobiology.Dr. Mullis has authored several major patents. His patented inventions include the PCR technology and UV-sensitive plastic that changes color in response to light. His most recent patent application covers a revolutionary approach to instantly mobilize the immune system to neutralize invading pathogens and toxins, leading to the formation of his latest venture, Altermune Technologies, of which he is the Chief Scientific Advisor.His many publications include “The Cosmological Significance of Time Reversal” (Nature), “The Unusual Origin of the Polymerase Chain Reaction” (Scientific American), “Primer-directed Enzymatic Amplification of DNA with a Thermostable DNA Polymerase” (Science), and “Specific Synthesis of DNA In Vitro via a Polymerase Catalyzed Chain Reaction” (Methods in Enzymology).Dr. Mullis has written an autobiographical book titled Dancing Naked in the Mind Field published by Pantheon Books in 1998.Mullis received a Nobel Prize in chemistry in 1993, for his invention of the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Dr. Mullis was awarded the Japan Prize in 1993 for the PCR invention. His many other awards include the Thomas A. Edison Award (1993); California Scientist of the Year Award (1992); the National Biotechnology Award (1991); the Gairdner Award, Toronto, Canada (1991); the R&D Scientist of the Year (1991); the William Allan Memorial Award of the American Society of Human Genetics (1990); and the Preis Biochemische Analytik of the German Society of Clinical Chemistry and Boehringer Mannheim (1990).Dr. Mullis was presented the honorary degree of Doctor of Science from the University of South Carolina in 1994. He was inducted into the Inventors Hall of Fame in 1998.He lived in Newport Beach with his wife, Nancy Cosgrove Mullis, until his death on August 7, 2019.

name: Gottlieb Haberland
description: He   entered the University of Vienna and  obtained his Ph.D in  1876. He went to the University of Tübingen (1877) to study under Simon Schwendener, who subsequently influenced Haberlandt’s belief that structure and function should be studied together. Haberlandt first pointed out the possibilities of the culture of isolated tissues, plant tissue culture.He suggested that the potentialities of individual cells via tissue culture and also suggested that the reciprocal influences of tissues on one another could be determined by this method. Since Haberlandt's original assertions methods for tissue and cell culture have been realized, leading to significant discoveries in Biology and Medicine. His original idea presented in 1902 was called totipotentiality: “Theoretically all plant cells are able to give rise to a complete plant.The more efficient C-4 photosynthesis in land plants depends on a specialized Kranz (German for wreath) leaf anatomy was  first described by Gottlieb Haberlandt in 1904.He taught  botany at the Technical Academy in Graz. In 1910 Haberlandt succeeded Schwendener in the chair of plant physiology at the University of Berlin, where he established the Institute for Plant Study.He wrote a book Physiologische Pflanzenanatomie (1884; “Physiological Plant Anatomy”) in which he distinguished 12 tissue systems based on function (mechanical, absorptive, photosynthetic, etc.). He died on  30 January 1945 (aged 90) in Berlin.

name: Ross Granville Harrison
description: Ross Granville Harrison was born in 1870 in Germantown, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, United States. He earned a BA degree from John Hopkins University at a young age of nineteen. He was well-known for his work on animal tissue culture and embryonic development. He has also studied the embryology of oyster. He won several awards, one of the many being John J. Carty Award for the Advancement of Science

name: Ingo Potrykus
description: Ingo Potrykus is professor of plant science at plant science institute of swiss federal institute of technology (ETH), Zurich who was born on 5th december, 1933, in germany. He completed his degree in biology at university of cologne and completed his doctoral degree at the max-plansk institute for plant breeding research, cologne, germany. After several years being at institute of plant physiology, university of hohenhelm, he was appointed group leader at max-planck institute for plant genetics, ladenburg, germany. He went to Basel, Switzerland to establish a plant genetic engineering area at the federal institute of technology. He became professor at plant science which was focusing on biotechnology of plants. He retired from this institute in 1999 at the age of 65. Potrykus and his research team gave attention to genetic engineering yield stability and food quality of crops such as rice, wheat, millet, sorghum and cassava, because of the announcement of the upcoming crisis issue of malnutrition in developing countries. Golden rice is one of the most significant creations done till now. He took funding from the Rockefeller Foundation and combined with Peter Beyer and together launched a project to develop Golden Rice, that would become a seven-year, $2.6 million. He retired in 1999 and Ingo Potrykus became president of the International Humanitarian Golden Rice Board and devoted his energy to guiding Golden Rice to farmers across the many problems of a GMO-crop. He has established collaboration with 14 rice institutions in India, China, Vietnam, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Philippines.

name: Peter Beyer
description: Peter Beyer studied Biology at the universities of Marburg and Freiburg. He was awarded his doctorate in Cell Biology from the University of Freiburg and received his postdoctoral lecture qualification in 2000. Afterwards he was appointed Professor for Cell Biology at the Faculty of Biology. Since 2001 Beyer is Vice-Director Plant Biotechnology of the Centre for Applied Biosciences (ZAB) in Freiburg.He became Principal Investigator in the ProVitaMinRice Consortium, a program funded by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation and one of the selected Grand Challenges in Global Health projects.Peter Beyer’s research focusses on the biochemistry, molecular biology and regulation of the plant [prenyl-lipid metabolism (sterols, vitamins E and K, carotenoids and focuses on applied pathway engineering to improve the nutritional value of crop plants.  CPeter Beyer pioneered the metabolic engineering of plants with engineering the beta-carotene biosynthetic pathway into rice endosperm, published 2000 in Science, which is widely appreciated as one of the success stories of Synthetic Biology.He is the co inventor of golden rice and has a patent on Engineering the provitamin A (beta-carotene) biosynthetic pathway into (carotenoid-free) rice endosperm.He is awarded 2002 European Science Prize and was voted as “Most notable and influential people in agricultural, environmental or industrial biotech research of the last ten years” by the readers of Nature Biotechnology in 2006.

name: Frederick Sanger
description: Frederick Sanger was born on August 13, 1918, in Rendcombe, England, to a physician father and the wealthy daughter of a cotton manufacturer. He developed an interest in science from his physician father and his older brother, with whom he enjoyed the outdoors. In 1939, he graduated in biochemistry from St John's College, Cambridge. A conscientious objector, he stayed on at the University of Cambridge during the Second World War to study the nutritional benefit of lysine in potatoes under biochemist Albert Neuberger.Sanger worked on  determining insulin's amino acid sequence, which had never been done before. Using chemistry and chromatography, and by mixing standard techniques with novel ones, he developed a method to read the amino acid sequence of insulin and found that this protein is actually made up of two amino acid chains linked together by disulphide bonds.He was the first person to obtain a protein sequence.By doing so, Sanger proved that proteins were ordered molecules and by analogy, the genes and DNA that make these proteins should have an order or sequence as well.In 1962  he joined the Medical Research Council (MRC) and worked with researchers, such as Francis Crick, who were studying DNA. Crick's enthusiasm for the subject was mesmerizing and soon Sanger had left the study of proteins for the challenge of sequencing DNA. Once again, Sanger combined the old with the new and developed an original DNA sequencing method, now known as the Sanger Method. In 1977, he and his colleagues published the sequence of a virus genome of over 5,000 base pairs.Sanger won his first Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1958 for his work on the structure of protein.In 1980, Sanger was awarded his second Nobel Prize in chemistry for his contributions to the study of DNA.

name: Gregor Mendel
description: Gregor Johann Mendel was born in 1822 in the Australian Empire (now known as Czechia). He partook a two-year philosophy program. At University of Vienna he devoted time to mathematics and physics along with which he studied anatomy and philosophy of plants and learnt how to use the microscope in the summer of 1853. In 1854 Mendel planned a major experiment on hybridization at his own ministry. This ministry’s major aim was to explore hybridization and transmission of characters in the following generations and chose Pisum sativum , an edible pea plant, to conduct his studies due to its numerous benefits like versatile and distinct varieties, ease of culture and control of pollination with high proportion of the excessive germinations.  With time as genetic studies were pushed down at molecular level, Mendelian's gene theory became acceptable and started being acknowledged as Father of Genetics.Sir Mendel received several laurels, one significant being Nobel Prize for his work on genetics.

name: Rosalind Franklin
description: Rosalind Elsie Franklin, commonly known as Rosalind Franklin was born in 1920 in London, England. She did her graduation in a natural sciences and later got herself enrolled for a PhD in Physical Chemistry. But she later gave up her post doctorate work due to troubles with her mentor and enrolled herself for a research position under British coal utilization research association in 1942 and examined coal and graphite structures. Rosalind Franklin worked as a successful X-ray crystallographer, unearthing some of the major properties of DNA which gradually helped to discover the correct description of the double helix structure of DNA. Though she made immense scientifically important contributions to DNA, her work was unrecognized in her lifetime, titling her names like 'wronged heroin', 'dark lady of DNA', 'forgotten heroin', and 'feminist icon'.But later, as by Fate’s decree, scientists concluded that Franklin was a contributor and 'equal player' in the discovery process of DNA in April 2023 based on evidence. Franklin published 19 articles on coals and carbon, a few prominent being on 'thermal expansion of coals and carbonized coals', 'study of 5 structure of carbonaceous solids by measurements of true and apparent densities: part one - coals', 5 on DNA and 21 on viruses. She received many invitations to speak at various conferences all over the world upon her research work on viruses, which also awarded her several awards and enabled her garner professional recognition.

name: Daisy Roulland-Dussoix
description: Daisy Roulland-Dussoix (9 September 1936 at  Geneva, Switzerland – 5 January 2014 at  Lancy, Switzerland) was a Swiss molecular microbiologist. During her undergraduate education, she worked as a researcher on restriction enzymes. Daisy Roulland-Dussoix was born on September 9, 1936 in Geneva, Switzerland. His parents were Edmond Louis Dusoit and Elsa Magatha (Sauerbrey) Dusoit. Daisy Roulland-Dussoix (née Daisy Dussoix) received her first degree in chemistry and biology at the University of Geneva (1958), followed by her doctorate in biophysics (1964). While a graduate student at the University of Geneva, she discovered restriction enzymes, bacterial enzymes that attach to DNA. This discovery led to the advancement of molecular biology, opening the door to genome editing and cloning technology. His lawyer, Werner Arber, won the Nobel Prize in 1978 for this discovery. Later in her career, Daisy transferred to UCSF, where she worked on proto-oncogenes with Harold Varmus, who won the Nobel Prize in 1989. In 1980 Daisy moved to Paris and became director of the Mycoplasma Laboratory at the Pasteur Institute. She failed in January 2014. While working on his PhD with Swiss microbial geneticists Werner Arber and Eduard Kellenberger, he first demonstrated that immunity from bacteria (bacteriophages) led to the discovery that restriction and treatment of enzymes were important. Molecular Biology Tools. These enzymes affect the cleavage of DNA from specific sequences by enzymes at specific points, unless the enzymes are protected by enzymatic modification through the DNA base. This system prevents the spread of bacterial infections. Grete Kellenberger-Gujer's previous research showed that phage DNA can be degraded by the host's bacterial cells. Daisy Dussoix and Werner Arber showed in two publications that this process requires enzymes, paving the way for the discovery and isolation of relevant restriction and repair enzymes. They first presented these results at the First International Congress on Biophysics in Stockholm in 1961. In 1964, supported by a postdoctoral fellowship from Jane Pall Childs, Dussoit moved to Stanford University in the United States to work with Robert Lehman. From 1968 he was an assistant professor in the Department of Microbiology at the University of California, San Francisco, where he continued to work on DNA restriction and repair with Herbert W Boyer.

name: Ananda Mohan Chakrabarty
description: He was an Indian American microbiologist, scientist, and scholar, born in 1938 in Saintia.  He received his PhD from University of Calcutta .  He is known for his work in the field of evolutionary theory and his role in the creation of genetically modified organisms using plasmid transfer while working at the General Electric Company. He is also known to develop effective treatments against chronic problems like cancer and many other important health problems. He was awarded the Civil Padma Shri award by the Government of India in 2007 for his contributions to genetic engineering technology.

name: Françoise barré-sinoussi
description: Françoise Barré-Sinoussi is a French virologist and Director of the Regulation of Retroviral Infections Division and Professor at the Institut Pasteur in Paris, France who was born on 30 July 1947, Paris, France. from a very young age, she was very interested in science. After realizing that she was very talented in the sciences compared to her humanities courses, She expressed her interest to her parents that she would like to attend university to study science or become a researcher. She was more interested in becoming a doctor but at the time she was under the false impression that studying medicine was both more expensive and lengthier than a career in science. After two years studying at the university, she tried to find part-time work in a laboratory to ensure that she had made the right career choice. After searching for laboratory work for a year, she was finally appointed at the Pasteur Institute. Her part-time work at the Pasteur Institute quickly became full-time. She was attending university only to take the exams and had to rely on her friends’ class notes because she was not regularly attending class. However shei was actually scoring higher on her exams than before because she finally had the motivation because she had realized a career in science was what she wanted. In 1974,  She received her PhD, and interned in the U.S. National Institutes of Health before returning to the Pasteur Institute in Montagnier's unit. During the early AIDS epidemic in 1981 to 1984, while Working with Luc Montagnier, Jean-Claude Chermann and others at the institute, from a biopsied swollen lymph node of a patient at risk for AIDS, she isolated and grew a retrovirus later known as HIV-1. This discovery helped in the development of diagnostic tests to aid and  to control the spread of the virus, for informing policy on the treatment of people living with AIDS, and for many important advancements in the science of HIV/AIDS that ultimately saved countless lives. In 1988, she started her own laboratory at the Pasteur Institute.

name: KIRAN MAZUMDAR SHAW
description: Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw was born in 1953 in Bangalore, Karnataka . She has stidued biology, zoology ,malting and brewing.  She is the Executive Chairman and Founder of Biocon Limited and Biocon Biologics Limited, a biotechnology company based in Bangalore, India, and former Chairman of the Indian Institute of Management, Bangalore.She has consistently proven herself eligible for many laurels. But to name a few, she has received Padma Bhushan award and has been listed among the 100 most influential people in the world by TIME magazine. She received an honorary doctorate from Davangere University, India, in recognition of her contribution to the field of biotechnology.

name: GERHARD JOHANNES PAUL DOMAGK
description: GERHARD JOHANNES PAUL DOMAGK was born in 1895 in Łagów, Poland. Being a German pathologist and bacteriologist , he has immensely contributed to scientific field.He is credited with the discovery of antibiotic sulfonamide chrysoidine (KL730). He was awarded several laurels like Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, Paul Ehrlich and Ludwig Darmstaedter Prize.

name: Maurice Lemoigne
description: Maurice Lemoigne was born in 1883 in Paris. He graduated as an engineer from the National Agronomic Institute through a scholarship. He mainly worked in the fields of biochemistry, microbiology, and chemistry. He participated in research on nitrification applied to water purification at Muntz laboratory. He worked on improving soil fertilization methods. In 1928, he was appointed professor of analytical chemistry at the National Agronomic Institute in agricultural chemistry which he developed into biological chemistry. He was also appointed as the director of the Lille fermentation laboratory, wherein he observed acidification of aqueous suspension of Bacillus megaterium. He was the first to observe biodegradable plastic from Bacillus megaterium. He received several awards from Academy of Sciences, Agriculture and was also honoured by the country for his non scientific contributions.

name: Brigitte Askonas
description: Brigitte Askonas was born in 1923 in Vienna, Austria. She studied biochemistry from McGill University and later did her post-graduation work in the School of Biochemistry at the University of CambridgeShe joined the staff of National Institute for Medical Research (NIMR) . At NIMR, she started her research on biosynthesis of polypeptides in milk proteins and discovered that peptides were synthesized from amino acids. For a few years, she studied different sites of antibody formation to develop better understanding of antibody molecules and cells of the immune system. She also studied about B cells and the fate of antigen and antibody formation. In 2007, she was made a Foreign Associate of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States and honored by the Robert Koch Prize. She was also elected a member of the Royal Society, in 1973 and a member of the Academy of Medical Sciences.

name: Dr. Hubert Schoemaker
description: Dr. Hubert Schoemaker's was born in 1950 in Deventer, Netherlands He studied Chemistry at Notre Dame University, USA. He later opted for a doctorate in biochemistry at MIT then completed his doctorate in 3 years .  He involved himself in research and his focus area was ribonucleic acid under the guidance of Paul Schimmel. He also studied genetic code and the mechanism of protein synthesis.He also involved himself in biotechnology commercialization. He later developed several pioneering diagnostic tests related to immunoassays. He became one of the co-founder of Centocor, one of the first American biotechnology companies dedicated to commercializing monoclonal antibody diagnostics and therapeutics. He was the founder of Eastern Technology Council. He was also the founder of Neuronyx which had the objective of the developing bone marrow stem cells for therapeutic applications.

name: Jean purdy
description: Jean Purdy, or Jean Marian Purdy was born in 1945 in Cambridge, England. She trained to become a nurse at Addenbrook’s hospital in Cambridge. She started working as a nurse, but later out of dissatisfaction, she switched to work on tissue rejection. She was transferred to a different hospital in her home country where she performed her first open heart surgeries, heart transplants.Her main fields of work were nursing and embryology. Jean Purdy has significantly worked over the technology of IVF. But her role in developing the technique was ignored for 30 years.

name: Wilhelm Roux
description: Roux was born in Jena, Germany, on 9 June 1850, the only son of Clotilde Baumbach and a university fencing master, F. A. Wilhelm Ludwig Roux.  Roux attended the University of Jena in 1869, but his education was halted after the first year because of his service in the military during the Franco-Prussian War. When he returned from the war, he continued to take classes and was admitted into the University of Jena medical faculty. He passed his medical examination in 1877 and became a licensed doctor.Roux made several substantial contributions to the field of experimental embryology. In 1881 he used Charles Darwin’s theory of natural selection to describe the relationships between cells and the development of organs in embryos, and published these ideas in Der Kampf der Theile im Organismus.Few years later, in 1883, Roux discussed another theory that would later develop into the Roux-Weismann theory of mosaic development in his paper “Über die Bedeutung der Kerntheilungsfiguren.”Roux also conducted many influential experiments on the early development of the embryo.From  series of experiments with green frog blastomeres at the 2- and 4-cell stages of development,He concluded from these experiments that blastomeres at the earliest stages of development already have a predetermined fate, meaning they develop mosaically.He founded the first journal of experimental embryology, called Archiv für Entwicklungsmechanik der Organismen.Roux died on 15 September 1924 in Halle, Germany.

name: Ludwig Haberlandt
description: Ludwig Haberlandt (1 February 1885 - 22 July 1932), pioneer in hormonal contraception, was born in Graz, where he graduated from the university in 1909 in medicine summa cum laude and began his career as a physiologist. The idea of temporary hormonal contraception in the female body entered his mind in February 1919, when he was already Professor of Physiology in Innsbruck. He pursued his project ambitiously and by 1921 demonstrated temporary hormonal contraception in a female animal by transplanting ovaries from a second, pregnant, animal. From 1923, after further successful scientific work in this field, he began highlighting the importance of clinical trials in presentations. From then, he was criticized by his colleagues, who accused him of hindering unborn life. His idea was contradictory to the moral, ethic, religious and political agendas of that time in Europe. In 1927 official reports escalated, his family was ostracized by the local population, and Ludwig Haberlandt refused any further interviews. Against all opposition, in 1930 he began clinical trials after successful production of a hormonal preparation, Infecundin, by the G. Richter Company in Budapest, Hungary. Although at the peak of his scientific career, he was unable to pursue other scientific agendas because of the disputed contraception project.After he committed suicide, on 22 July 1932, scientific discussion about hormonal contraception ceased until 1970 when scientists began referring to his earlier medical and scientific work.
